text: The United States Constitution does not mention sexual freedom, but the United States Supreme Court, whose main job is to interpret the Constitution, has found that the Constitution does provide the right to privacy and self-determination. The Court has not defined this right very clearly, but it does recognize the right to, for instance, an abortion within limits, and the right to use and receive information about contraceptives. According to the Supreme Court, the basis for this right comes from the protections of the Bill of Rights. For instance, the First Amendment's freedom of religion, freedom of speech, and freedom of association. The Third Amendment's protection of each citizen's home from the quartering of soldiers in peacetime. The Fourth Amendment's protection of each citizen's person and home against unreasonable search and seizure. The Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination. And the Ninth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination. The Ninth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination. And the Ninth Amendment's protection from governmental infringement of certain unspecified rights of the people. It's both fortunate and unfortunate that those rights have not been specified. Besides finding this right to privacy, the Supreme Court has indicated that groups considered to be what they call discrete and insular minorities, such as racial and ethnic groups, need special protection under the Constitution, particularly to ensure that they have a right to privacy. They have equal access to this nation's political and governmental processes. So, with all these protections, why hasn't the Supreme Court upheld the rights of gays and lesbians to live and work without discrimination? The answer is not because of any lack of cases. The Court ducked a number of gay rights issues in the 1970s and wiggled out of one Virginia case in 1976 by affirming a lower court decision without hearing any arguments or giving any reasons. In short, the Supreme Court has hoped the issue of gay rights would go away. Why? Well, because with all of these other holdings setting the trend, the Court would appear extremely inconsistent if it decided against gay rights. And yet, if it decided in favor of gay rights, despite negative public opinion, the Court might undermine its authority and jeopardize its ability to enforce unpopular rulings. After all, the United States Supreme Court has no army. It has no army to back up its decisions, nor does it have control of federal funds with which to coerce compliance. Another possible reason for the Court's reluctance to handle gay rights cases is that the Court's two liberal members, Thurgood Marshall and William Brennan, fear they would be outvoted on the issue. And they've been delaying gay rights cases because they fear a bad decision would be worse than no decision. If Brennan and Marshall are stalling for a time when the Court will be more liberal, it is doubtful they will be outvoted. They will live long enough. Brennan is 77, Marshall is 75 and in poor health. And if Reagan is re-elected, we probably will have an extremely conservative Supreme Court for the rest of this century. So, tonight we have asked Leonard Graff, the legal director of National Gay Rights Advocates, to tell us what cases are pending in the nation's courts, including the Supreme Court this year, and what the chances are that 1984 will be a major year in the history of gay rights, for better or for worse. National Gay Rights Advocates, which is based in San Francisco, is a private, non-profit law firm that acts as a clearinghouse for a large number of gay rights cases throughout the nation. It is similar to the American Civil Liberties Union in that it fines lawyers nationwide who are willing to donate their time to specific cases. As legal director for the past year and a half, Leonard Graff coordinates those legal efforts. They're all yours. Thank you very much. I'm pleased to be here tonight to talk to you about the current gay rights litigation that's going on around the country. And what I'd like to do is sort of break it down by different categories. And rather than lecture, I just assume make it more of a discussion. So, if you have questions as I'm going along, feel free to raise your hands and interrupt. I understand that a good number of you are not law students. And so, I'll try. I'll try to keep my terms as general and in the lay language as possible. If you don't understand something I'm talking about, please let me know and I'll try to explain it the best I can. I'd like to start out first talking about an area which is very important to gay rights advocates. It's an issue we've been working on for about five years, and that's the immigration naturalization issue. And what I'll probably do is conclude with an issue which I think many of you will find important, which is the rights of gay students in this country. And by no means is this issue settled at all. In the area of immigration naturalization, we won at Gay Rights Advocates a very important victory in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California in the case of Carl Hill versus INS. And the Immigration Nationality Act prohibits homosexuals from entering the country. However, you don't find the word homosexual anywhere in the immigration nationality. What you find is a Supreme Court decision which has interpreted the language of the act to exclude homosexuals. And the precise terminology that they interpreted was psychopathic personality. Since gay people are afflicted with a psychopathic personality, they must be excluded from the country. Now the question is, which we raised in the Carl Hill case, is how do you determine who is a homosexual? It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual. It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual. It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual. It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual. The only way to make this determination under the law is through an examination by a public health service doctor. That doctor must examine the arriving alien and say to that alien, to our gay issue of what is known as a placer certificate. Then the INS can exclude the person from the country. Now the government's position is that a person is capable to decide for themselves whether or not they're gay. And if they say they're gay, they are gay, and can be excluded from the country. This is the issue. The U.S. District Court here in the Northern District of California agreed with gay rights advocates that a doctor's certificate from the Public Health Service must issue. The case involved Carl Hill who was a tourist who's here for pleasure and a journalist, a photographer for a London newspaper. Now the same issue rose again in the case of Richard Longstaff which is a case that we have just filed a petition for review in the United States Supreme Court, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals decision. The Fifth Circuit sits in New Orleans. Mr. Longstaff is a resident of Dallas, Texas. He's been here about 20 years now. He came here on a valid immigrant visa. He subsequently opened up two boutiques, clothing stores, and hairdressing salons. He employs about 20 citizens of this country. He pays over $100,000 a year in income taxes, and our government has said to Richard Longstaff, you're not good enough to be an American citizen. Why has our government said that? Because Richard Longstaff is gay, and that is the position that the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld. So what we have now is a clear conflict between two circuits. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals here has affirmed the decision of Carl Hill. What we did is file a petition in the Supreme Court asking them to review the Fifth Circuit decision and to resolve the conflict between the two different courts of appeals. We feel that there's a good chance that the Supreme Court will agree to hear the case, and part of the reason is that there's no constitutional issues. We're not asking this court, this very conservative Supreme Court, to create any new constitutional issues of rights for gay people. All we're asking them to do is resolve what is essentially an inter-agency dispute, and it's more of a question of statutory construction. So our petition was filed in that case at the end of January. The government's brief is due on Friday, and the new case clerk at the Supreme Court tells me that the Supreme Court will probably make a decision in three to four weeks after that. So we could be seeing a decision in that soon. Here in the Ninth Circuit the government filed a petition for what's known as a rehearing on bond, meaning they wanted the entire Court of Appeals, the Ninth Circuit, to review that decision, and the Ninth Circuit refused to grant that petition. That came down January 17th. So what we'll find too is that the government will undoubtedly be asking the Supreme Court to also review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be inspired, I think, to ask for that review is because as a result of our victory at the lower court level, we filed a petition for attorneys' fees in the amount of $300,000. So that's what we're asking them to do. In addition, on the congressional level, there's been some legislation that is going to be introduced by Barney Frank from Massachusetts, and we helped him draft that legislation which would change the exclusions so that it would eliminate the sexual deviance and psychopathic personalities. The next area I want to talk to you about is the military. The military has an absolute policy that gay people cannot serve, and the only exception to this policy is not really for the status of being gay, but someone who commits a homosexual sexual act. If they renounce that act, they'll say, oh, Christ, was I drunk last night. I didn't know what I was doing. You know, it was a mistake. It's never going to happen again. Please let me stay in the military. They can stay in. Other than that, everybody else is out. Now, the progress that we've made in the last few years, at least at the discharge, will be under honorable conditions and will be entitled to full benefits. However, for somebody who's chosen to make a career of the service, this can still be pretty severe after you've been in for so many years to lose all the benefits in your particular chosen career. And to have the government, in effect, say to you, well, you're not good enough to fight and die for your country, either. We have a test case pending in Washington, D.C. Circuit, Court of Appeals now, involving a man who was originally stationed out here at Monterey, the Language Institute. That's Jim Jonenberg. He's a specialist in Korean cryptology. He had been in the service for nine years. Three months before his discharge, he had been given a $12,000 reenlistment bonus. He was on probation after accommodation after accommodation. They thought he was an excellent soldier until they found out he was gay. They kicked him out. The strategy of bringing the case in the District of Columbia was that by reputation, the District of Columbia's Circuit Court of Appeals is the most liberal in the country. And in addition, the issue had been decided here in the Ninth Circuit some years ago by a case that we had brought and lost in a case that's known as Beller versus Willendorf. So there was no avenue available for redress here. And the strategy also would be that if we were able to get into the D.C. courts, then that would resolve the issue for all soldiers because the issue of jurisdiction and venue revolved around where was the defendant located. It was our position that the Department of Defense and the headquarters of the Department of Navy were located in Washington, D.C. And the government fought us tooth and nail on this. In fact, two-thirds of their brief, they argued that the court didn't have jurisdiction. And essentially for the merits of the case, all they did was say, well, another court out there in San Francisco decides the issue, and so it's what nothing about that is said. Well, we won half that case. We won the jurisdictional issue. We lost on the merits. Now we're in the Court of Appeals, and our strategy we found backfired on us because the odds maybe were 1,000 to 1 of drawing three conservative judges in which room. Three of the most conservative judges you could ever want to have. One of them started asking questions about did the right to privacy include the right to have sex with animals? And you have to start off at this level. You can't be too optimistic about the result. One of the other judges who was a Reagan appointee to the bench was a former professor of law at the University of Chicago Law School and a student who did work for gay rights advocates. He was a volunteer last summer, had this judge as a professor for constitutional law, and when this man came to the issue of abortion rights, he said, I'm Catholic, and I have nine children, and that's enough said about abortion. Let's move on. So as you can see, we're not too optimistic about that case. There was a really great brief filed by the American Civil Liberties Union in that. An amicus parodic brief, a friend of the court brief. And what the ACLU did was to trace the rationale that the military uses for excluding gays, and they compared it to the same rationale that the military used to segregate blacks from the service, to say, look, white men are never going to sleep in the same barracks as black men. A white soldier is never going to sleep with a black soldier. How can a black maintain control and demand respect? And this is the same kind of thing they say about gays and lesbians in the service. And it's a very good, very detailed brief, and very enlightening. I hope that the court takes some note of it. The paradox to what's going on in the military is that if you're a civilian employee of the military, there's almost, it's almost impossible to get rid of you, regardless of what, what, what's going on. What kind of activity you're involved in. The 934 of Appeals has recently held that a person who is a convicted child molester still could not be discharged from the Navy, absent a showing that there was some connection with his job duties in the Navy, what we call the nexus between his activity and his job requirements. So, in another area that we find the problem is that people who want to make a career, out of the military, they make every effort to get rid of them as soon as they can. And those who want to get out, somebody discovers after they're in the service that they realize that their sexual orientation is not really what they thought it was, and they come to the commanding officer and they say, I'm gay. These people flounder around in the system, often for a year or more before they're discharged, even though the regulations are so mandatory. And how we resolve that problem, I can't really say, but it really is sort of a schizophrenic kind of thing. It's a kind of attitude where they just can't make up their mind what they want. Other problems that we found now, too, is that the military, in some instances, are trying to prosecute soldiers for asking for a discharge, saying that they enlisted fraudulently, that they knew at the time that they enlisted that they were gay, that their enlistment therefore was fraudulent, and they're trying to have them prosecuted. There's a case up on appeal in the Tenth Circuit Court in Denver. And it's been there for some time, so we should see a decision pretty soon in that case. Another thing that we find the military is doing now is suing people who've gone through ROTC. And apparently, they have some kind of program where they subsidize their educational benefits. And in the case that came before us last year, there was a person who went through medical school, of course, in the U.S. Army, and then when he finished, said, I'm sorry, I can't do my six-year stint not because I knew I was un-gay. The Army said, well, I think we're going to have to sue you for $60,000 to reimburse us for the cost of your education. We were willing to defend this man, but he didn't have the desire to go through several years of litigation. It takes a lot of forward to go through that, and what he did instead was file a bankruptcy. In any case, the military picked up the bill, or for those of you who are working, I guess we all picked up the bill in a sense. Which leads me to the next thing that we've done is, based on some data we've collected over the last couple of years, we can make a pretty good estimate that the cost of separating gay people from the military is at least $20 million a year. That on average, the military separates about 1800 soldiers a year from the service. because of homosexuality and that based on a recent RAND Corporation study cost of training a soldier through basic training first 22 weeks is a hundred thousand dollars so simple arithmetic will show that that's 18 million dollars and my experience is most of the people that are being discharged have been around for a lot more than 22 weeks what's the situation with conscription where somebody turns 19 and supposed to go to the post office says i'm gay what how does the system do with them well you probably wouldn't necessarily tell the postmaster but you you would still have to register and it wouldn't really become an issue until you were called up and at that time what happens is that you're given a questionnaire and asked you to list all of your childhood diseases and being broken bones and there's a square somewhere says how you've looked at your homosexual attendance what happens if you check the box and say you are so afflicted then you will be deferred you will not be taken conducted in the military you cannot be conducted if you check if you do not check the box you could be inducted however if you fraudulently if you know that you're gay you don't check that box you are subject to penalties of as much as five years in prison and five thousand dollars if they could substitute through case intense um let's talk about deployment discrimination a little bit something that's been in the news just recently was a b one finally passed both houses and sitting on duke's desk waiting for signature what most people don't know in this state is that all that bill does is codify a supreme court decision which already extends sexual orientation discrimination, protection to all employers in the state. The only thing is that not all employees are covered. And this was the case called Gay Law Students for Specific Telephone and Telegraph. And I say it doesn't cover all employees because it only covers those employees who are open or out on the job, their employers got to know that they're gay. Because part of what the Supreme Court of California said in that case was that being out on the job is political activity. And that in this state, an employer may not discriminate against an employee based on political activity. And political activity is much broader than partisan politics. It goes beyond the Democratic and Republican parties, includes political causes, women's rights, labor union rights, gay rights. So what the AB1 does is... Protect those people who are not out on their job, and it also gives them an administrative remedy by going through the Fair Employment and Housing Administration, rather than having to file a suit directly in court. Other employment work that we're doing at Gay Rights Advocates, one involves a suit against an act known as the Helms Bill in Oklahoma. The Helms Bill is essentially similar to the Briggs Initiative that was up here in California a few years ago. While the Briggs Initiative was defeated here in California, it's law in Oklahoma. And we filed a suit challenging that bill, and we lost at the District Court level in Oklahoma. We have that case now up in the Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in Denver. We had oral arguments last September, so we're looking for a decision any time that case. The Helms Bill... As you can recall, the main issue was First Amendment freedom of expression. That was the main cause of action. There was also, we raised, due process, need for protection arguments, as well as the right to privacy. And this kind of litigation, I'll tell you, for some of you who are law students and don't realize it, and the rest of you are not, we're often, quite frankly, flying by the seat of our pants. I mean, this is new. And when we're in the courts, and we're making new law, we're making new laws. We're making new laws. And the gay rights litigation that's going on in this country has essentially taken place in the last 10 to 15 years. Ten years ago, GRA didn't exist, and there weren't any more gay legal organizations around the country. And most of the states still had sodomy laws in the books, and it's not uncommon to find all sorts of oppressive legislation in the books. So we don't have a lot to look toward in terms of precedents. We have to analogize a lot to the struggles that were won in the women's prison system. And that's what we're trying to do. We're trying to make sure that we're making the right decisions. Thank you. Yes, sir. In the case of the movement of the first amendment, the gay rights movement went through the black movement and other first amendment types of cases. The privacy decisions that came out of the abortion litigation, and contraceptive litigation, that's what we sort of draw from. Sometimes, we make analogies and sometimes we just make them for the theories. You have to go in there. So we feel, gay rights advocates, we have a very aggressive litigation posture that if we don't go into court and file suit, then we've lost before we've even seen the even started. There is, in a sense, nothing to lose about going into court, because in the case of the Helmsville situation, the bill's on the books. And if we lose, the bill's still on the books, so what did we lose? But at least we go in there and fight, we have a chance of winning. And in addition, we feel there's some other benefits. There's educational benefits, there's consciousness raising, there's all the press we've got. We've engendered a lot of good press. People just cannot believe the situations I've been ascribing to you tonight about the military and immigration, these kind of things happening in America today in 1984. It's just incredible. And so we feel there's a certain value to bringing lawsuits to win or lose. And it's making a statement generally, too, that you've pushed this community around for just so long, and now it's your game, but we can play it, too, and we're going to be there and we're going to fight and we're going to win. But maybe we're not going to win all the time. But you're not going to knock us out of the ring, because we're going to be right back there fighting every time. That's what gay rights advocacy is all about. I didn't really follow up on your argument regarding the fact that you said you ran some personal time lawsuit, but that's the thing that you cannot be gay with a teacher. Well, actually, the law is so broad that it could exclude straight people, as well, because the language prohibits homosexual activity and homosexual conduct, neither of which is defined as engaging in what we would call homosexual sexual conduct. It's the mere mention, the mere discussing of homosexual rights could subject a teacher to a disciplinary hearing and a possible discharge from their employment. But the terms in the law are so vague and so general that it's hard to tell exactly what could be done. And I think that's something that's going to be brought within the purview of the law. But essentially, it's expressions, it's talking about and discussing anything about homosexuality. What was the name of the case about gay law students versus a specific telephone term? In regard to that case and AB1, it sounded, it sounded, what I heard was that dismissing employees on those grounds is prohibited. Wouldn't AB1 also apply to job applicants and to promotion processes? Yes, it does specific telephone and telegraphies. It does. All types of employment-related discrimination. Promotions, fringe benefits, the hiring process, the whole ball of things. But AB1, if we're going to see it to the extent that it's going to have a change? Yes. My understanding is that it would cover, I haven't taken a look at it in a while. Spouses. Yeah, that's a whole other issue and I think that's sort of the issue of the 80s is the rights of gay couples. We're going to be doing some gay couples litigation. We did one case already and we have two pending now, which I'll go into a little bit. It's one that we're going to do in Columbia, Maryland, which involves the American Automobile Association and their motor club. They offer a discount to married couples, but not to a gay couple, a lesbian couple. And we're demanding that they extend that same benefit to gay couples. The case arose in Columbia, Maryland, which is situated in Howard County. Howard County has a very broad anti-discrimination ordinance. It prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation as well as marital status. Really, this is sort of a marital status type discrimination as opposed to sexual orientation. However, gay people cannot be legally married anywhere in the country. So, it necessarily impacts on the gay community very heavily. So, that's in the administrative process now. And I think whoever loses that is probably going to appeal. So, we're looking toward a long court battle out there. We have another case that's in sort of pre-adversary position right now down in Southern California in La Jolla, where there's a gay couple that's been living together for six years. They have a relationship contract that governs their relationship. And they also are having a dispute with AAA, this time with the automobile insurance. And AAA offers, apparently, a $20,000 fine. A 20% spousal discount. But this couple, of course, cannot qualify for that spousal discount. So, we just might have to sue AAA on that issue as well. There are a number of areas where gay people, because they cannot be lawfully married, have fewer benefits, employment fringe benefits and taxation and so on, pension plans. And we don't necessarily, as I said earlier, expect to win all these cases. Especially in the beginning. What we're looking at is at least a 10-year program. But we're going to start raising the consciousness of the insurance industry. There are already at least two insurance carriers that I'm aware of that offer what they call domestic partnership or adult living companion. They have different euphemisms. But they offer the plan already. And I think, essentially, these discounts on marketing, I don't think there's really any sound insurance reasons why they offer it. And so, it's just going to be a matter of breaking it down. And when a few insurance carriers start offering the program, and they find out that it's profitable, I think we'll find many more start offering it as well. Some other employment cases we're involved in. One involves a high school guidance counselor in Mad River, Ohio. Marjorie Rowland came out on her job, and she didn't have her contract renewed simply because of her sexual orientation. She won at the district court level. Won an order for reinstatement and a $40,000 judgment for lost wages. And the school district appealed the case to the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati. We had oral arguments on that case last June. So I think we'll be seeing a decision on that one pretty soon now, too. In Minnesota, there's a judge there by the name of Robert Crane Winton, who's been on the bench for about 19 years. And according to all his peers, he's a very able and competent judge. But he's being recommended for removal because he would not take a vow of celibacy. Crane Winton is gay. His sexual orientation came to light when he was arrested and charged with solicitation for prostitution. Which he subsequently entered a plea to two misdemeanors, soliciting male prostitutes. Now, what makes the case an interesting one of discrimination is that two years earlier, a straight judge in Minnesota was arrested and pled out to the same charges with female prostitutes. He was given a reprimand and a $250 fine. Crane Winton has been ordered to pay a $46,000 fine, and, recommended for removal from the bench. And, the straight judge was not asked to take a vow of celibacy. Now, the vow of celibacy comes from the fact that Minnesota has a sodomy statute on the books. Most people think that sodomy statutes prohibit gay people from having sex. Well, what most people don't understand is that that same statute in virtually every state that has a sodomy statute, prohibits all sexual activity, other than between a husband and wife in a missionary position. So, even straight people are subject to the same law. In most states, it's a felony. And, I'm telling you, these laws are enforced. In Nevada, a man was recently given 22 consecutive life terms for committing the abominable crime against nature. And, that case involved a teenager. And, so you can say, well, okay, this is minors. It's not the same. I can assure you a straight man would have never received the same sentence. And, in addition, another case I'm just aware of in Nevada where there was a scorned lover who called the police because he walked in on his lover having sex with another man. And, the police came out, and they caught the people, what we say, flagrant delecto, in bed. This man was arrested. He was charged with sodomy. He was given a 20-year sentence. First offense. So, I'm telling you, these laws, they're in effect. They're enforced. And, even more than that, they're something that we are attacking around the country because they're a great psychological barrier to attaining gay rights in this country. It's sort of the bedrock of discrimination. How can we give employment protection to criminals? And, city councils sit around and debate extending civil rights orders to protect people on the basis of sexual orientation. How can we give civil rights protection to criminals? So, this is the kind of thing that we have to get rid of in these sodomy laws. We have participated recently in a national conference of some other gay organizations and sponsored by the National American Civil Liberties Union in New York last fall where we are going to put together a strategy attacking the remaining 25 sodomy statutes in this country. We're going to go after them one by one and knock them off. We're going to figure out what's the best form. Do we want to be in the state court? Do we want to be in the federal court? What is the correct time? What is the correct mode for attacking these cases? Is it going to be in the criminal context? Is it going to be a civil challenge? And, we're going to go after these statutes and we're going to get rid of them. There was a significant victory in sodomy challenge litigation last year in the case of Baker v. Wade which came out of the U.S. District Court in Dallas, Texas which ruled that that sodomy statute in Texas was unconstitutional. The Amarillo District Attorney decided to appeal that decision even though the State Attorney General did not. That case is now before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit of New Orleans and oral arguments have been scheduled for the second week in March. That case, I feel quite certain, will also be appealed to the Supreme Court regardless of who wins. Now, what happened in that case that's sort of a new twist was that at the Court of Appeals level the District Attorney said we've got to have a sodomy statute on the books because we needed to control AIDS. Well, the time that that sodomy statute was passed I assure you nobody had ever even heard of AIDS. And, furthermore, the State and the District Attorney did not litigate the AIDS issue at the trial level. And so it was our position at the Court of Appeals level that it's too late. We cannot bring up a new issue for the first time at the Court of Appeals level. That same argument is being made in sodomy challenge to the law in Georgia. And there the case is on appeal before the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. The other case that's pending now that could have some impact quite considerable impact, in fact on sodomy litigation in the future is a case which is presently before the U.S. Supreme Court. This is the Uplinger case which came out of the State of New York. A couple years ago, by way of background the New York Court of Appeals which is the highest court in that state struck down the sodomy statute in New York. They said it was unconstitutional. The state applied for a writ of cert to the U.S. Supreme Court. They asked the U.S. Supreme Court to review the decision. The U.S. Supreme Court refused to grant the writ. So the court action became final. What we still have left on the books was a law which made it illegal to ask somebody to engage in deviant sexual behavior what they called loitering for solicitation of deviant sexual behavior which is defined as sodomy. So when a man named Robert Uplinger was arrested and charged under that statute the end result in the court was well, if it's perfectly lawful to engage in the act why should it be illegal to ask somebody to engage in the act? And they struck down the solicitation statute also. This time, the District Attorney in Buffalo appealed the decision or asked for a writ of cert to the U.S. Supreme Court and the U.S. Supreme Court granted it. And the speculation was that the reason they granted it was that they had changed their mind about the Onofre case and they really wanted to review the underlying issues of the sodomy legislation in New York. And in fact, that was an argument that was made in the petition by the DA. Now, some events happened since that petition was filed and when the final brief was filed for the State of New York, the District Attorney in Buffalo, he did not argue that the sodomy statute needed to be reconsidered. And an interesting twist, too, was that the Attorney General of the State of New York, Robert Abrams filed an amicus brief supporting the decision of the New York Court of Appeals that the law was not constitutional. So you had, in effect, the State's Attorney General and a city DA on opposite sides of the same issue. NGRA filed an amicus brief in the Supreme Court arguing that the petition was impromptly granted and that they would just throw the whole thing out without deciding it. And what we're hoping is that they are not going to read the underlying issues because, for one thing, they're not properly before the Court. There wasn't an issue in the lower court decision. And secondly, they were not adequately briefed because, as I said, it was not an issue. Oral arguments have already been presented in that case. We're expecting a decision on the matter. We're hoping that it will be made later this spring. And depending on what happens in that case, it could have a significant impact on litigation for a good number of years to come. Another area of litigation that's going on is in the area of security clearances. Security clearances are necessary for people, many people who work for the government or work for private industry that do contracts with the government. They're in the areas of energy and defense. And what security clearance means is that the government says that you are okay to look at classified information and feel that you're not going to default this information. There's different levels of security clearances. Gay people over the years have had a great deal of problems getting security clearances. And what we found is that the government's policy on this is somewhat inconsistent. They do not have an interagency plan or a set of guidelines or criteria. Each agency decides on its own. And there's an awful lot of discretion that can be exercised. What we found is a recent trend where in many agencies a person can get a security clearance. Some agencies, so-called intelligence agencies, I call them the police agencies, the FBI, the CIA, the National Security Agency, are hanging in there tough, and they will not grant security clearances to anybody that they know is gay. There's been some recent litigation against the CIA. There's one case that was filed more than a year ago in the District of Columbia District Court. It's before Judge Barrington Parker. And he's been sitting on motions for summary judgment in that case for more than a year now. There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles, the U.S. District Court down there, involving John Green, who was an engineer with a company known as TRW. And he's worked with TRW. He's worked with TRW, I believe, for 13 years. And he's never had any problems. The CIA, in fact, has never said that he leaked any information, divulged any information. But basically what they said was that he was gay and that he was subject to blackmail when he was gay, and therefore made divulged information. So that argument breaks down when a person says, I'm not subject to blackmail. I'm open about my sexuality. My family knows. My friends know. It's no big deal to me. I don't know why it's a big deal to you. But to the CIA, it's still a big deal. And they can't, they just cannot understand why there might be some kind of, or might not be some kind of problem here. So that case is pending in the U.S. District Court. The government just yesterday filed this brief, they filed a motion to dismiss. They said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the case. Based on solemn immunity, they said the government did not consent to be sued in this case. And they also said that the judiciary would be infringing on the executive branch of government by getting involved in this matter. They said the CIA had absolute discretion to decide who gets the security clearance and who does not. So there will be a responsible treaty filed on that on March 2nd. I'll talk only about two more issues. One is, briefly, some First Amendment cases that we're involved in. We find that a number of gay community newspapers, like here in San Francisco, we have the Bay Area Reporter, are being censored at a number of prisons around the country. Prisoners who want to keep in touch with their gay communities are not being allowed to read these papers. So we're going to be involved in a suit probably at, if we're lucky, the Congressional Correctional Institute in Kentucky, and maybe one here at the Lompoc prison, and possibly one down in Texas as well. And then the last thing that I want to talk about is the rights of gay students. I went to, well, I went to several undergraduate schools. I graduated from Michigan State University, which is where I first got involved in gay political causes. And as a student, I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a claim on a banner on the two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events. And Michigan State University is on a main thoroughfare with 40,000 cars a day pass through this intersection. We wanted to put a banner that said Gay Pride Week, and the administration wouldn't let us. So we filed an action against the university. We didn't win, but it was probably because we weren't adequately prepared, because we found out from sort of some of our sources close to the administration that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year, because they'd probably be in some pretty serious trouble. And so the next year, we made an application to put up the banner and ended up without any problems. Now this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which I helped lobby for in 1971, last year they allowed that gay students be kicked out of fraternities simply because they were gay. So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance it's not going to be worth a whole lot, and it's not enforced. So there are continuing problems going on. We found that there's a school called Andrews College which is trying to kick out two students because they allege they're gay. There's a private college in the suburbs of Chicago that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student who's completed all of his coursework and said this person's gay and doesn't meet the criminal character requirements of our schools. He can't handle his degree. We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville, the school has official, granted official university recognition to the student organization there, but they won't grant them any office space or any funding or any of the benefits that might go along with official recognition. There's two cases going on in Texas right now involving the rights of students to get recognition at their campus. And my last big gay rights case before I came to the West Coast involved a lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C. because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate and to the law school gay student organizations. So there are still a lot of lawsuits involving students as well as many other areas that are important. We can become complacent here in California that doesn't have a sodomy statute anymore. We have a lot of protections. People to a great extent are maybe a lot more relaxed. They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community as sort of this old hat. But in most parts of the country, there's still a lot of problems. And that's what National Gay Rights Advocates is all about. It's writing these new laws about the rest of the country. Is Gay Rights Advocates taking on any cases involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality? Does that seem to be something in California that is sort of an issue and is very important to consider? Yeah, there's a lot of problems in that area. We have not taken on any cases involving that issue. I can't say we've been presented with any. What we do in determining what cases to take is we basically wait for people to come to us, which is not much of a problem. I get calls every day. A day doesn't go by. They don't get at least one call saying they're concerned about some kind of discrimination or adverse action. But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet. I think what you do talk about is in housing, screenwriters have been pointing out that this city, Denver, has a law that says two unrelated individuals cannot live together. And this is often against gay couples. It's the status of those and there's nothing being done about it. We haven't had any complaints in a long time about that kind of problem. That is a way of certainly discriminating against gay people without being so forthright as saying that we're not going to allow two gay people to live together. The history of that kind of legislation, I'm not so sure was necessarily anti-gay, but was intended to keep noise down and to protect sort of family-type environments. But it certainly didn't have an impact on gay people. Some years like that, it's very subtle with legislation. In some states like Virginia, it's very blatant.

segments.text: The United States Constitution does not mention sexual freedom, but the United States Supreme Court, whose main job is to interpret the Constitution, has found that the Constitution does provide the right to privacy and self-determination.
The Court has not defined this right very clearly, but it does recognize the right to, for instance, an abortion within limits, and the right to use and receive information about contraceptives.
According to the Supreme Court, the basis for this right comes from the protections of the Bill of Rights.
For instance, the First Amendment's freedom of religion, freedom of speech, and freedom of association.
The Third Amendment's protection of each citizen's home from the quartering of soldiers in peacetime.
The Fourth Amendment's protection of each citizen's person and home against unreasonable search and seizure.
The Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination.
And the Ninth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination.
The Ninth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination.
And the Ninth Amendment's protection from governmental infringement of certain unspecified rights of the people.
It's both fortunate and unfortunate that those rights have not been specified.
Besides finding this right to privacy, the Supreme Court has indicated that groups considered to be what they call discrete and insular minorities,
such as racial and ethnic groups, need special protection under the Constitution,
particularly to ensure that they have a right to privacy.
They have equal access to this nation's political and governmental processes.
So, with all these protections, why hasn't the Supreme Court upheld the rights of gays and lesbians to live and work without discrimination?
The answer is not because of any lack of cases.
The Court ducked a number of gay rights issues in the 1970s and wiggled out of one Virginia case in 1976
by affirming a lower court decision without hearing any arguments or giving any reasons.
In short, the Supreme Court has hoped the issue of gay rights would go away.
Why?
Well, because with all of these other holdings setting the trend,
the Court would appear extremely inconsistent if it decided against gay rights.
And yet, if it decided in favor of gay rights, despite negative public opinion,
the Court might undermine its authority and jeopardize its ability to enforce unpopular rulings.
After all, the United States Supreme Court has no army.
It has no army to back up its decisions, nor does it have control of federal funds with which to coerce compliance.
Another possible reason for the Court's reluctance to handle gay rights cases
is that the Court's two liberal members, Thurgood Marshall and William Brennan,
fear they would be outvoted on the issue.
And they've been delaying gay rights cases because they fear a bad decision would be worse than no decision.
If Brennan and Marshall are stalling for a time when the Court will be more liberal,
it is doubtful they will be outvoted.
They will live long enough.
Brennan is 77, Marshall is 75 and in poor health.
And if Reagan is re-elected, we probably will have an extremely conservative Supreme Court for the rest of this century.
So, tonight we have asked Leonard Graff, the legal director of National Gay Rights Advocates,
to tell us what cases are pending in the nation's courts, including the Supreme Court this year,
and what the chances are that 1984 will be a major year in the history of gay rights,
for better or for worse.
National Gay Rights Advocates, which is based in San Francisco,
is a private, non-profit law firm that acts as a clearinghouse for a large number of gay rights cases throughout the nation.
It is similar to the American Civil Liberties Union in that it fines lawyers nationwide
who are willing to donate their time to specific cases.
As legal director for the past year and a half, Leonard Graff coordinates those legal efforts.
They're all yours.
Thank you very much.
I'm pleased to be here tonight to talk to you about the current gay rights litigation that's going on around the country.
And what I'd like to do is sort of break it down by different categories.
And rather than lecture, I just assume make it more of a discussion.
So, if you have questions as I'm going along, feel free to raise your hands and interrupt.
I understand that a good number of you are not law students.
And so, I'll try.
I'll try to keep my terms as general and in the lay language as possible.
If you don't understand something I'm talking about, please let me know and I'll try to explain it the best I can.
I'd like to start out first talking about an area which is very important to gay rights advocates.
It's an issue we've been working on for about five years, and that's the immigration naturalization issue.
And what I'll probably do is conclude with an issue which I think many of you will find important,
which is the rights of gay students in this country.
And by no means is this issue settled at all.
In the area of immigration naturalization, we won at Gay Rights Advocates a very important victory
in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California in the case of Carl Hill versus INS.
And the Immigration Nationality Act prohibits homosexuals from entering the country.
However, you don't find the word homosexual anywhere in the immigration nationality.
What you find is a Supreme Court decision which has interpreted the language of the act to exclude homosexuals.
And the precise terminology that they interpreted was psychopathic personality.
Since gay people are afflicted with a psychopathic personality, they must be excluded from the country.
Now the question is, which we raised in the Carl Hill case, is how do you determine who is a homosexual?
It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual.
It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual.
It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual.
It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual.
The only way to make this determination under the law is through an examination by a public health service doctor.
That doctor must examine the arriving alien and say to that alien,
to our gay issue of what is known as a placer certificate.
Then the INS can exclude the person from the country.
Now the government's position is that a person is capable to decide for themselves whether or not they're gay.
And if they say they're gay, they are gay,
and can be excluded from the country. This is the issue. The U.S. District
Court here in the Northern District of California agreed with gay rights
advocates that a doctor's certificate from the Public Health Service must
issue. The case involved Carl Hill who was a tourist who's here for pleasure
and a journalist, a photographer for a London newspaper. Now the same
issue rose again in the case of Richard Longstaff which is a case that
we have just filed a petition for review in the United States Supreme Court, the
Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals decision. The Fifth Circuit sits in New Orleans.
Mr. Longstaff is a resident of Dallas, Texas. He's been here about 20 years now.
He came here on a valid immigrant visa. He subsequently opened up two boutiques,
clothing stores, and hairdressing salons. He employs about 20 citizens of this
country. He pays over $100,000
a year in income taxes, and our government has said to Richard Longstaff,
you're not good enough to be an American citizen. Why has our government said that? Because Richard Longstaff is gay, and that is the
position that the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld. So what we have now is a
clear conflict between two circuits. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals here has
affirmed the decision of Carl Hill. What we did is file a petition in the Supreme
Court asking them to review the Fifth Circuit decision and to resolve the
conflict between the two different courts of appeals. We feel that there's a good
chance that the Supreme Court will agree to hear the case, and part of the reason
is that there's no constitutional issues. We're not asking this court, this very
conservative Supreme Court, to create any new constitutional issues of rights for gay
people. All we're asking them to do is resolve what is essentially an inter-agency dispute,
and
it's more of a question of statutory construction. So our petition was filed in that case at
the end of January. The government's brief is due on Friday, and the new case clerk at
the Supreme Court tells me that the Supreme Court will probably make a decision in three
to four weeks after that. So we could be seeing a decision in that soon. Here in the Ninth
Circuit the government filed a petition for what's known as a rehearing on bond, meaning
they wanted the entire Court of Appeals, the Ninth Circuit, to review that decision, and
the Ninth Circuit refused to grant that petition. That came down January 17th. So what we'll
find too is that the government will undoubtedly be asking the Supreme Court to also review
the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be inspired, I
think, to ask for that review is because as a result of our victory at the lower court
level, we filed a petition for attorneys' fees in the amount of $300,000. So that's
what we're asking them to do.
In addition, on the congressional level, there's been some legislation that is going
to be introduced by Barney Frank from Massachusetts, and we helped him draft that legislation which
would change the exclusions so that it would eliminate the sexual deviance and psychopathic
personalities.
The next area I want to talk to you about is the military. The military has an absolute
policy that gay people cannot serve, and the only exception to this policy is not really
for the status of being gay, but someone who commits a homosexual sexual act. If they renounce
that act, they'll say, oh, Christ, was I drunk last night. I didn't know what I was doing.
You know, it was a mistake. It's never going to happen again. Please let me stay in the
military. They can stay in.
Other than that, everybody else is out. Now, the progress that we've made in the last few
years, at least at the discharge, will be under honorable conditions and will be entitled
to full benefits. However, for somebody who's chosen to make a career of the service, this
can still be pretty severe after you've been in for so many years to lose all the benefits
in your particular chosen career.
And to have the government, in effect, say to you, well, you're not good enough to fight
and die for your country, either.
We have a test case pending in Washington, D.C. Circuit, Court of Appeals now, involving
a man who was originally stationed out here at Monterey, the Language Institute. That's
Jim Jonenberg. He's a specialist in Korean cryptology. He had been in the service for
nine years. Three months before his discharge, he had been given a $12,000 reenlistment bonus.
He was on probation after accommodation after accommodation. They thought he was an excellent
soldier until they found out he was gay. They kicked him out.
The strategy of bringing the case in the District of Columbia was that by reputation, the District
of Columbia's Circuit Court of Appeals is the most liberal in the country. And in addition,
the issue had been decided here in the Ninth Circuit some years ago by a case that we had
brought and lost in a case that's known as Beller versus Willendorf.
So there was no avenue available for redress here.
And the strategy also would be that if we were able to get into the D.C. courts,
then that would resolve the issue for all soldiers
because the issue of jurisdiction and venue revolved around where was the defendant located.
It was our position that the Department of Defense and the headquarters of the Department of Navy
were located in Washington, D.C.
And the government fought us tooth and nail on this.
In fact, two-thirds of their brief, they argued that the court didn't have jurisdiction.
And essentially for the merits of the case, all they did was say,
well, another court out there in San Francisco decides the issue,
and so it's what nothing about that is said.
Well, we won half that case.
We won the jurisdictional issue.
We lost on the merits.
Now we're in the Court of Appeals, and our strategy we found backfired on us
because the odds maybe were 1,000 to 1 of drawing three conservative judges
in which room.
Three of the most conservative judges you could ever want to have.
One of them started asking questions about did the right to privacy
include the right to have sex with animals?
And you have to start off at this level.
You can't be too optimistic about the result.
One of the other judges who was a Reagan appointee to the bench
was a former professor of law at the University of Chicago Law School
and a student who did work for gay rights advocates.
He was a volunteer last summer, had this judge as a professor
for constitutional law, and when this man came to the issue
of abortion rights, he said, I'm Catholic, and I have nine children,
and that's enough said about abortion.
Let's move on.
So as you can see, we're not too optimistic about that case.
There was a really great brief filed by the American Civil Liberties Union
in that.
An amicus parodic brief, a friend of the court brief.
And what the ACLU did was to trace the rationale that the military uses
for excluding gays, and they compared it to the same rationale
that the military used to segregate blacks from the service,
to say, look, white men are never going to sleep in the same barracks
as black men.
A white soldier is never going to sleep with a black soldier.
How can a black maintain control and demand respect?
And this is the same kind of thing they say about gays and lesbians in the service.
And it's a very good, very detailed brief, and very enlightening.
I hope that the court takes some note of it.
The paradox to what's going on in the military is that if you're a civilian employee
of the military, there's almost, it's almost impossible to get rid of you, regardless of what,
what, what's going on.
What kind of activity you're involved in.
The 934 of Appeals has recently held that a person who is a convicted child molester still could not
be discharged from the Navy, absent a showing that there was some connection
with his job duties in the Navy, what we call the nexus
between his activity and his job requirements.
So, in another area that we find the problem is that people who want to make a career,
out of the military, they make every effort to get rid of them as soon as they can.
And those who want to get out, somebody discovers after they're in the service
that they realize that their sexual orientation is not really what they thought it was,
and they come to the commanding officer and they say, I'm gay.
These people flounder around in the system, often for a year or more before they're discharged,
even though the regulations are so mandatory.
And how we resolve that problem, I can't really say, but it really is sort
of a schizophrenic kind of thing.
It's a kind of attitude where they just can't make up their mind what they want.
Other problems that we found now, too, is that the military, in some instances,
are trying to prosecute soldiers for asking for a discharge, saying that they enlisted fraudulently,
that they knew at the time that they enlisted that they were gay,
that their enlistment therefore was fraudulent, and they're trying to have them prosecuted.
There's a case up on appeal in the Tenth Circuit Court in Denver.
And it's been there for some time, so we should see a decision pretty soon in that case.
Another thing that we find the military is doing now is suing people who've gone through ROTC.
And apparently, they have some kind of program where they subsidize their educational benefits.
And in the case that came before us last year, there was a person who went through medical school,
of course, in the U.S. Army, and then when he finished, said, I'm sorry, I can't do my six-year stint
not because I knew I was un-gay.
The Army said, well, I think we're going to have to sue you for $60,000 to reimburse us for the cost of your education.
We were willing to defend this man, but he didn't have the desire to go through several years of litigation.
It takes a lot of forward to go through that, and what he did instead was file a bankruptcy.
In any case, the military picked up the bill, or for those of you who are working, I guess we all picked up the bill in a sense.
Which leads me to the next thing that we've done is, based on some data we've collected over the last couple of years,
we can make a pretty good estimate that the cost of separating gay people from the military is at least $20 million a year.
That on average, the military separates about 1800 soldiers a year from the service.
because of homosexuality and that based on a recent RAND Corporation study cost of training
a soldier through basic training first 22 weeks is a hundred thousand dollars
so simple arithmetic will show that that's 18 million dollars and my experience is most of
the people that are being discharged have been around for a lot more than 22 weeks
what's the situation with conscription where somebody turns 19 and supposed to go to the
post office says i'm gay what how does the system do with them well you probably wouldn't
necessarily tell the postmaster but you you would still have to register and it wouldn't really
become an issue until you were called up and at that time what happens is that you're given a
questionnaire and asked you to list all of your childhood diseases and being broken bones and
there's a square somewhere says how you've looked at your homosexual attendance
what happens if you check the box and say you are so afflicted then you will be
deferred you will not be taken conducted in the military you cannot be conducted
if you check if you do not check the box you could be inducted however if you fraudulently
if you know that you're gay you don't check that box you are subject to penalties of as
much as five years in prison and five thousand dollars if they could substitute through
case intense
um let's talk about deployment discrimination a little bit something that's been in the news
just recently was a b one finally passed both houses and sitting on duke's desk waiting for
signature what most people don't know in this state is that all that bill does is codify
a supreme court decision which already extends
sexual orientation
discrimination, protection to all employers in the state.
The only thing is that not all employees are covered.
And this was the case called Gay Law Students for Specific Telephone and Telegraph.
And I say it doesn't cover all employees because it only covers those employees who
are open or out on the job, their employers got to know that they're gay.
Because part of what the Supreme Court of California said in that case was that being
out on the job is political activity.
And that in this state, an employer may not discriminate against an employee based on
political activity.
And political activity is much broader than partisan politics.
It goes beyond the Democratic and Republican parties, includes political causes, women's
rights, labor union rights, gay rights.
So what the AB1 does is...
Protect those people who are not out on their job, and it also gives them an administrative
remedy by going through the Fair Employment and Housing Administration, rather than having
to file a suit directly in court.
Other employment work that we're doing at Gay Rights Advocates, one involves a suit
against an act known as the Helms Bill in Oklahoma.
The Helms Bill is essentially similar to the Briggs Initiative that was up here in California
a few years ago.
While the Briggs Initiative was defeated here in California, it's law in Oklahoma.
And we filed a suit challenging that bill, and we lost at the District Court level in
Oklahoma.
We have that case now up in the Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in Denver.
We had oral arguments last September, so we're looking for a decision any time that case.
The Helms Bill...
As you can recall, the main issue was First Amendment freedom of expression.
That was the main cause of action.
There was also, we raised, due process, need for protection arguments, as well as the right
to privacy.
And this kind of litigation, I'll tell you, for some of you who are law students and don't
realize it, and the rest of you are not, we're often, quite frankly, flying by the seat of
our pants.
I mean, this is new.
And when we're in the courts, and we're making new law, we're making new laws.
We're making new laws.
And the gay rights litigation that's going on in this country has essentially taken place
in the last 10 to 15 years.
Ten years ago, GRA didn't exist, and there weren't any more gay legal organizations around
the country.
And most of the states still had sodomy laws in the books, and it's not uncommon to find
all sorts of oppressive legislation in the books.
So we don't have a lot to look toward in terms of precedents.
We have to analogize a lot to the struggles that were won in the women's prison system.
And that's what we're trying to do.
We're trying to make sure that we're making the right decisions.
Thank you.
Yes, sir.
In the case of the movement of the first amendment, the gay rights movement went
through the black movement and other first amendment types of cases.
The privacy decisions that came out of the abortion litigation, and contraceptive litigation,
that's what we sort of draw from.
Sometimes, we make analogies and sometimes we just make them for the theories.
You have to go in there.
So we feel, gay rights advocates, we have a very aggressive litigation posture that
if we don't go into court and file suit, then we've lost before we've even seen the
even started. There is, in a sense, nothing to lose
about going into court, because in the case of the Helmsville situation,
the bill's on the books. And if we lose,
the bill's still on the books, so what did we lose? But at least we go in there and fight, we have a chance
of winning. And in addition, we feel there's some other benefits. There's educational
benefits, there's consciousness raising, there's all the press we've got.
We've engendered a lot of good press. People just cannot believe the situations
I've been ascribing to you tonight about the military and immigration,
these kind of things happening in America today in 1984.
It's just incredible. And so
we feel there's a certain value to bringing lawsuits to win or lose.
And it's making a statement generally, too, that you've pushed this
community around for just so long, and now it's your
game, but we can play it, too, and we're going to be there and we're going to fight
and we're going to win. But maybe we're not going to win all the time.
But you're not going to knock us out of the ring, because we're going to be right back there fighting every time.
That's what gay rights advocacy is all about.
I didn't really follow up on your argument
regarding the fact that you said you ran some personal time
lawsuit, but that's the thing that you cannot be gay
with a teacher. Well, actually, the law is so broad
that it could exclude
straight people, as well, because the language prohibits
homosexual activity and homosexual conduct,
neither of which is defined as engaging in what we would call homosexual sexual
conduct. It's the mere mention, the mere discussing
of homosexual rights could subject a teacher to a disciplinary hearing and a possible
discharge from their employment. But the terms
in the law are so vague and so general that it's hard
to tell exactly what could be done.
And I think that's something that's going to be brought within the purview of the law.
But essentially, it's expressions, it's talking about and discussing
anything about homosexuality.
What was the name of the case about gay law students versus a specific telephone term?
In regard to that case and AB1, it sounded, it sounded, what I heard was that dismissing employees on those
grounds is prohibited.
Wouldn't AB1 also apply to job applicants and to promotion processes?
Yes, it does specific telephone and telegraphies.
It does. All types of employment-related discrimination. Promotions, fringe benefits, the hiring process,
the whole ball of things.
But AB1, if we're going to see it to the extent that it's going to have a change?
Yes.
My understanding is that it would cover, I haven't taken a look at it in a while.
Spouses.
Yeah, that's a whole other issue and I think that's sort of the issue of the 80s is the rights of gay couples.
We're going to be doing some gay couples litigation.
We did one case already and we have two pending now,
which I'll go into a little bit.
It's one that we're going to do in Columbia, Maryland, which involves the American Automobile Association
and their motor club.
They offer a discount to married couples, but not to a gay couple, a lesbian couple.
And we're demanding that they extend that same benefit to gay couples.
The case arose in Columbia, Maryland, which is situated in Howard County.
Howard County has a very broad anti-discrimination ordinance.
It prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation as well as marital status.
Really, this is sort of a marital status type discrimination as opposed to sexual orientation.
However, gay people cannot be legally married anywhere in the country.
So, it necessarily impacts on the gay community very heavily.
So, that's in the administrative process now.
And I think whoever loses that is probably going to appeal.
So, we're looking toward a long court battle out there.
We have another case that's in sort of pre-adversary position right now down in Southern California in La Jolla,
where there's a gay couple that's been living together for six years.
They have a relationship contract that governs their relationship.
And they also are having a dispute with AAA, this time with the automobile insurance.
And AAA offers, apparently, a $20,000 fine.
A 20% spousal discount.
But this couple, of course, cannot qualify for that spousal discount.
So, we just might have to sue AAA on that issue as well.
There are a number of areas where gay people, because they cannot be lawfully married,
have fewer benefits, employment fringe benefits and taxation and so on, pension plans.
And we don't necessarily, as I said earlier, expect to win all these cases.
Especially in the beginning.
What we're looking at is at least a 10-year program.
But we're going to start raising the consciousness of the insurance industry.
There are already at least two insurance carriers that I'm aware of that offer what they call domestic partnership
or adult living companion.
They have different euphemisms.
But they offer the plan already.
And I think, essentially, these discounts on marketing,
I don't think there's really any sound insurance reasons why they offer it.
And so, it's just going to be a matter of breaking it down.
And when a few insurance carriers start offering the program,
and they find out that it's profitable,
I think we'll find many more start offering it as well.
Some other employment cases we're involved in.
One involves a high school guidance counselor in Mad River, Ohio.
Marjorie Rowland came out on her job,
and she didn't have her contract renewed simply because of her sexual orientation.
She won at the district court level.
Won an order for reinstatement and a $40,000 judgment for lost wages.
And the school district appealed the case to the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati.
We had oral arguments on that case last June.
So I think we'll be seeing a decision on that one pretty soon now, too.
In Minnesota,
there's a judge there by the name of Robert Crane Winton,
who's been on the bench for about 19 years.
And according to all his peers, he's a very able and competent judge.
But he's being recommended for removal because he would not take a vow of celibacy.
Crane Winton is gay.
His sexual orientation came to light
when he was arrested and charged with solicitation for prostitution.
Which he subsequently entered a plea to two misdemeanors,
soliciting male prostitutes.
Now, what makes the case an interesting one of discrimination is that
two years earlier, a straight judge in Minnesota
was arrested and pled out to the same charges with female prostitutes.
He was given a reprimand and a $250 fine.
Crane Winton has been ordered to pay a $46,000 fine,
and,
recommended for removal from the bench.
And,
the straight judge was not asked to take a vow of celibacy.
Now,
the vow of celibacy comes from the fact that Minnesota has a sodomy statute on the books.
Most people think that sodomy statutes prohibit gay people from having sex.
Well,
what most people don't understand is that that same statute
in virtually every state that has a sodomy statute,
prohibits all sexual activity,
other than between a husband and wife in a missionary position.
So, even straight people are subject to the same law.
In most states, it's a felony.
And, I'm telling you, these laws are enforced.
In Nevada, a man was recently given 22 consecutive life terms
for committing the abominable crime against nature.
And, that case involved a teenager.
And, so you can say, well,
okay, this is minors.
It's not the same.
I can assure you a straight man would have never received the same sentence.
And, in addition,
another case I'm just aware of in Nevada
where there was a scorned lover
who called the police
because he walked in on his lover having sex with another man.
And, the police came out,
and they caught the people, what we say,
flagrant delecto,
in bed.
This man was arrested.
He was charged with sodomy.
He was given a 20-year sentence.
First offense.
So, I'm telling you, these laws,
they're in effect.
They're enforced.
And, even more than that,
they're something that we are attacking around the country
because they're a great psychological barrier
to attaining gay rights in this country.
It's sort of the bedrock of discrimination.
How can we give employment protection to criminals?
And, city councils sit around and debate extending civil rights orders
to protect people on the basis of sexual orientation.
How can we give civil rights protection to criminals?
So, this is the kind of thing
that we have to get rid of in these sodomy laws.
We have participated recently in a national conference
of some other gay organizations
and sponsored by the National American Civil Liberties Union
in New York last fall
where we are going to put together a strategy
attacking the remaining 25 sodomy statutes in this country.
We're going to go after them one by one and knock them off.
We're going to figure out what's the best form.
Do we want to be in the state court?
Do we want to be in the federal court?
What is the correct time?
What is the correct mode for attacking these cases?
Is it going to be in the criminal context?
Is it going to be a civil challenge?
And, we're going to go after these statutes
and we're going to get rid of them.
There was a significant victory
in sodomy challenge litigation last year
in the case of Baker v. Wade
which came out of the U.S. District Court in Dallas, Texas
which ruled that that sodomy statute in Texas
was unconstitutional.
The Amarillo District Attorney
decided to appeal that decision
even though the State Attorney General did not.
That case is now before
the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit of New Orleans
and oral arguments have been scheduled
for the second week in March.
That case, I feel quite certain,
will also be appealed to the Supreme Court
regardless of who wins.
Now, what happened in that case
that's sort of a new twist
was that at the Court of Appeals level
the District Attorney said
we've got to have a sodomy statute on the books
because we needed to control AIDS.
Well, the time that that sodomy statute was passed
I assure you nobody had ever even heard of AIDS.
And, furthermore,
the State and the District Attorney
did not litigate the AIDS issue at the trial level.
And so it was our position at the Court of Appeals level
that it's too late.
We cannot bring up a new issue for the first time
at the Court of Appeals level.
That same argument is being made
in sodomy challenge to the law in Georgia.
And there the case is on appeal
before the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta.
The other case that's pending now
that could have some impact
quite considerable impact, in fact
on sodomy litigation in the future
is a case which is presently before the U.S. Supreme Court.
This is the Uplinger case
which came out of the State of New York.
A couple years ago, by way of background
the New York Court of Appeals
which is the highest court in that state
struck down the sodomy statute in New York.
They said it was unconstitutional.
The state applied for a writ of cert
to the U.S. Supreme Court.
They asked the U.S. Supreme Court to review the decision.
The U.S. Supreme Court refused to grant the writ.
So the court action became final.
What we still have left on the books
was a law which made it illegal
to ask somebody to engage in deviant sexual behavior
what they called loitering for solicitation
of deviant sexual behavior
which is defined as sodomy.
So when a man named Robert Uplinger
was arrested and charged under that statute
the end result in the court was
well, if it's perfectly lawful to engage in the act
why should it be illegal to ask somebody to engage in the act?
And they struck down the solicitation statute also.
This time, the District Attorney in Buffalo
appealed the decision or asked for a writ of cert
to the U.S. Supreme Court
and the U.S. Supreme Court granted it.
And the speculation was
that the reason they granted it
was that they had changed their mind about the Onofre case
and they really wanted to review the underlying issues
of the sodomy legislation in New York.
And in fact, that was an argument
that was made in the petition by the DA.
Now, some events happened since that petition was filed
and when the final brief was filed
for the State of New York,
the District Attorney in Buffalo,
he did not argue that the sodomy statute
needed to be reconsidered.
And an interesting twist, too, was that
the Attorney General of the State of New York,
Robert Abrams filed an amicus brief
supporting the decision of the New York Court of Appeals
that the law was not constitutional.
So you had, in effect, the State's Attorney General
and a city DA on opposite sides of the same issue.
NGRA filed an amicus brief in the Supreme Court
arguing that the petition was impromptly granted
and that they would just throw the whole thing out
without deciding it.
And what we're hoping is that
they are not going to read the underlying issues
because, for one thing,
they're not properly before the Court.
There wasn't an issue in the lower court decision.
And secondly, they were not adequately briefed
because, as I said, it was not an issue.
Oral arguments have already been presented in that case.
We're expecting a decision on the matter.
We're hoping that it will be made later this spring.
And depending on what happens in that case,
it could have a significant impact
on litigation for a good number of years to come.
Another area of litigation that's going on
is in the area of security clearances.
Security clearances are necessary for people,
many people who work for the government
or work for private industry
that do contracts with the government.
They're in the areas of energy and defense.
And what security clearance means
is that the government says that you are okay
to look at classified information
and feel that you're not going to default this information.
There's different levels of security clearances.
Gay people over the years have had a great deal of problems
getting security clearances.
And what we found is that the government's policy
on this is somewhat inconsistent.
They do not have an interagency plan
or a set of guidelines or criteria.
Each agency decides on its own.
And there's an awful lot of discretion that can be exercised.
What we found is a recent trend where in many agencies
a person can get a security clearance.
Some agencies, so-called intelligence agencies,
I call them the police agencies,
the FBI, the CIA, the National Security Agency,
are hanging in there tough,
